frame.name: Sensation
frame.definition:
<def-root>This frame contains nouns that refer to sensations in different modalities. The FE <fen>Source</fen> is used for the phenomenon that gives rise to the sensation in question. The FE <fen>Percept</fen> is used for the characteristic quality of the sensation. In cases of veridical perception these are not typically distinguished from one another; we use the FE <fen>Percept</fen> as the default in these cases. With some nouns in this frame it is possible to express the being who experiences the sensation, or the part of the body of such a being. We mark such expressions with the FEs <fen>Perceiver_passive</fen> and <fen>Body_part</fen>, respectively. (The <ment>-passive</ment> part of this label serves to distinguish this FE from the Perceiver-Agentive FE used in other frames.) <ex></ex> <ex><fex name="Percept">The huge sand dunes, perpetually changing</fex>, <m>make</m> for a <fex name="Descriptor">surreal</fex> <t>sight</t>.</ex>
<ex><fex name="Perceiver_passive">Endill</fex> <m>heard</m> the <t>noise</t> <fex name="Percept">of glass smashing, plaster crumbling and furniture being broken</fex>.</ex>
<ex>The <t>feel</t> <fex name="Percept">of his strong fingers enclosing her small palm</fex> came as something of a shock to her system.</ex></def-root>

FE.name: Perceiver_passive
FE.definition: <def-root>This FE is only expressed with certain nouns in this frame, and then only with the help of a support verb, such as <ment>have</ment>: <ex><fex name="Perceiver_passive">I</fex> <ment>have</ment> a tingling <t>sensation</t> in my hands.</ex> With most nouns in this frame, a perceiver can only be expressed as the subject of a perception verb such as <ment>detect</ment> or <ment>sense</ment>: <ex>The dog <ment>detected</ment> the <t>scent</t> of explosives.</ex> In sentences like these the perceiver-denoting expression is not annotated because it is introduced by another perception word, which is treated independently in a different frame. </def-root>

FE.name: Source
FE.definition: <def-root>This is the entity or phenomenon which gives rise to the sensation. In cases of veridical sensation, this FE is not typically distinguished from <fen>Percept</fen>. Most of the phrases that express this FE can be paraphrased as <ment>from</ment>-phrases, e.g. <ex>The <t>smell</t> <fex name="Source">of the garlic</fex> made me hungry.</ex> <ex>The <t>smell</t> <fex name="Source">from the garlic</fex> made me hungry.</ex> <ex>The <t>smell</t> <ment>of garlic</ment> made me hungry.</ex> <ex>*The <t>smell</t> <ment>from garlic</ment> made me hungry.</ex> The first sentence, in which the object of the prepostion <ment>of</ment> is a definite NP, can be roughly paraphrased by the second sentence, which replaces the <ment>of</ment>-PP with a <ment>from</ment>-PP. This shows that the phrase <ment>of the garlic</ment> in the first sentence expresses <fen>Source</fen>. On the other hand, the third sentence, in which the object of the preposition <ment>of</ment> is a bare noun, cannot be so paraphrased. The bare-noun <ment>of</ment>-PPs express <fen>Percept</fen> rather than <fen>Source</fen>. <fen>Source</fen> can be expressed as the External Argument of a support verb, e.g. <ex><fex name="Source">This herb</fex> <ment>emits</ment> a strong <t>odour</t>. </ex></def-root>

FE.name: Percept
FE.definition: <def-root>The FE <fen>Percept</fen> is used for phrases that express the characteristic property of a sensation. Typically this characteristic property is described with reference to the entity or phenomenon that produces the sensation---that is why this FE can be difficult to distinguish from Source. It is possible for Source and Percept to be expressed separately, however: <ex><fex name="Source">This herb</fex> <gov>gives off</gov> a <t>smell</t> <fex name="Percept">of garlic</fex>.</ex> In cases in which it is impossible to distinguish between Source and Percept, Percept is used as the default FE. </def-root>

FE.name: Body_part
FE.definition: <def-root>This FE is assigned to phrases expressing the body part in which a sensation is located. Since touch is the least localized of sense modalities, words relating to haptic sensations are the ones most likely to occur with this FE: <ex>I have a tingling <t>feeling</t> <fex name="Body_part">in my hands</fex>.</ex> Words for other sense modalities can occasionally express this FE as well: <ex>There is a bitter <t>taste</t> <fex name="Body_part">on the back of my tongue</fex>.</ex> <ex>The ringing <t>sound</t> <fex name="Body_part">in my left ear</fex> distracted me during class. </ex></def-root>

FE.name: Descriptor
FE.definition: <def-root>A characterization of the sensation not covered by a more specific FE.</def-root>

FE.name: Ground
FE.definition: <def-root>This FE is the perceptual background against which the Phenomenon is experienced by the Perceiver.</def-root>

FE.name: Degree
FE.definition: <def-root>This FE describes how strong the sensation is.</def-root>

lexUnit.name: aroma.n
lexUnit.definition: COD: a pleasant and distinctive smell.

lexUnit.name: bouquet.n
lexUnit.definition: COD: the characteristic scent of a wine or perfume.

lexUnit.name: feel.n
lexUnit.definition: COD: a sensation given by an object or material when touched.

lexUnit.name: feeling.n
lexUnit.definition: COD: an emotional state or reaction

lexUnit.name: flavour.n
lexUnit.definition: COD: the distinctive taste of a food or drink.

lexUnit.name: fragrance.n
lexUnit.definition: COD: a pleasant, sweet smell or perfume

lexUnit.name: incense.n
lexUnit.definition: COD: a gum, spice, or other substance that is burned for the sweet smell it produces

lexUnit.name: noise.n
lexUnit.definition: FN: a loud, unpleasant sound

lexUnit.name: odor.n
lexUnit.definition: COD: a distinctive smell.

lexUnit.name: perception.n
lexUnit.definition: FN: the ability to become aware of something through the senses

lexUnit.name: perfume.n
lexUnit.definition: COD: a pleasant smell.

lexUnit.name: reek.n
lexUnit.definition: COD: a foul smell.

lexUnit.name: savour.n
lexUnit.definition: COD: a characteristic taste, flavour, or smell.

lexUnit.name: scent.n
lexUnit.definition: FN: a distinctive, pleasant smell

lexUnit.name: sensation.n
lexUnit.definition: COD: a physical feeling or perception resulting from something that happens to or comes into contact with the body

lexUnit.name: sense.n
lexUnit.definition: COD: an awareness of something or feeling that something is the case.

lexUnit.name: sight.n
lexUnit.definition: COD: the action or fact of seeing someone or something

lexUnit.name: smell.n
lexUnit.definition: COD: a quality in something that is perceived by this faculty

lexUnit.name: sound.n
lexUnit.definition: COD: vibrations which travel through the air or another medium and are sensed by the ear

lexUnit.name: stink.n
lexUnit.definition: COD: a strong, unpleasant smell

lexUnit.name: taste.n
lexUnit.definition: COD: the sensation of flavour perceived in the mouth on contact with a substance.

lexUnit.name: whiff.n
lexUnit.definition: COD: a smell that is smelt only briefly or faintly.

lexUnit.name: scene.n
lexUnit.definition: FN: a real or imaginary complex visual image, usually suggesting a prototypical situation

lexUnit.name: image.n
lexUnit.definition: FN: something that invokes the visual senses
